message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and rash suggest the most likely diagnosis of celiac disease, which is associated with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 serotypes. Macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells suggest megaloblastic anemia, which is not a common finding in celiac disease. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages suggest Whipple’s disease. Elevated urine tryptophan levels suggest Hartnup disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and rash are suggestive of celiac disease. HLA-DQ2 serotype is present in about 90% of individuals with celiac disease. None of the other options are associated with celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the itchy rash on elbows and knees suggest celiac disease, which is associated with HLA-DQ2 serotype. Macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells are seen in vitamin B12 and folate deficiency anemia, which is not associated with the patient’s symptoms. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages are seen in Whipple disease. Elevated urine tryptophan levels are seen in Hartnup disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the rash suggest that the most likely diagnosis is celiac disease. About 90% of patients with celiac disease have HLA-DQ2 serotype. The other options are not related to celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash and gastrointestinal symptoms suggest celiac disease. HLA-DQ2 serotype is commonly seen in patients with celiac disease. The other options are not associated with celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest celiac disease, which is associated with the HLA-DQ2 serotype. Macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells are a characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, which is not commonly associated with celiac disease. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages are seen in Whipple disease, which can also cause diarrhea and malabsorption, but the itchy rash on elbows and knees is not a typical presentation. Elevated urine tryptophan levels may suggest carcinoid syndrome, which can cause diarrhea and flushing, but it is not associated with celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest malabsorption and the rash is characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with celiac disease. HLA-DQ2 serotype is found in almost all patients with celiac disease. The other options are not associated with celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of diarrhea and flatulence after eating, as well as the itchy rash, are indicative of celiac disease, which is associated with the HLA-DQ2 serotype. Macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells are seen in megaloblastic anemia, which is not related to celiac disease. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages and elevated urine tryptophan levels are not associated with celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the itchy rash suggest celiac disease, which is often associated with HLA-DQ2 serotype. Elevated urinary tryptophan levels suggest Hartnup disease, and macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells suggest anemia. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages suggest Whipple disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of malabsorption, which is a common sign of celiac disease. The itchy rash on the patient’s elbows and knees also suggests it. HLA-DQ2 serotype is a genetic marker for celiac disease. Macrocytic, hypochromic red blood cells are seen in megaloblastic anemia, which is not commonly associated with celiac disease. PAS-positive intestinal macrophages are a histologic feature of Whipple disease. Elevated urine tryptophan levels are seen in Hartnup disease.
